claim: Americans earn less  than people in certain countries.

supporting.text: The median household income in the United States is lower than in countries like Switzerland and Norway, based on OECD data.

attacks.text: The median household income in the United States is lower than in countries like Switzerland and Norway, based on OECD data.
OECD data does not account for differences in cost of living, which is significantly higher in Switzerland and Norway compared to the U.S.
Even after adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), median disposable income in Switzerland and Norway remains higher than in the U.S.
The OECD median income metric excludes non-cash benefits like employer-provided healthcare, which are more prevalent in the U.S. than in Europe.
When total compensation (including benefits) is considered, U.S. workers still rank below several European nations in comprehensive income studies.

supporting.text: The average wage in the United States is higher than the global average but lower than in some high-income countries such as Luxembourg and Denmark.

attacks.text: The average wage in the United States is higher than the global average but lower than in some high-income countries such as Luxembourg and Denmark.
The comparison does not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in Luxembourg and Denmark than in the U.S.
Even after adjusting for cost of living, the purchasing power parity (PPP) adjusted wages in Luxembourg and Denmark still exceed those in the U.S.
The average wage metric is skewed by income inequality; median wages in the U.S. may be more comparable to those in Luxembourg and Denmark.
Median wages in Luxembourg and Denmark still surpass those in the U.S., even when accounting for income inequality.

supporting.text: Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that real incomes in the U.S. are lower than in certain countries with higher nominal GDP per capita.

attacks.text: Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that real incomes in the U.S. are lower than in certain countries with higher nominal GDP per capita.
PPP adjustments can be misleading because they rely on standardized baskets of goods that may not reflect actual consumption patterns in different countries.
Even if consumption patterns differ, PPP is still a widely accepted method by economists for comparing real incomes across countries.
The U.S. has higher disposable incomes after taxes and transfers, which PPP does not fully account for.
Taxes and transfers are important, but PPP focuses on purchasing power, which is a more direct measure of living standards.
Certain countries with higher PPP-adjusted incomes have much smaller populations, making comparisons less meaningful for a large economy like the U.S.
Population size does not negate the validity of PPP comparisons, as the metric is per capita and thus scales with population.

supporting.text: Income inequality in the U.S. results in a significant portion of the population earning less than the median income in more egalitarian high-income nations.

attacks.text: Income inequality in the U.S. results in a significant portion of the population earning less than the median income in more egalitarian high-income nations.
The U.S. median household income is higher than most high-income nations, even after accounting for inequality.
Median income comparisons often ignore cost-of-living differences, which are higher in the U.S. than in many other high-income nations.
Income inequality metrics don't account for non-wage benefits like employer-provided healthcare, which are more common in the U.S.
Non-wage benefits are unevenly distributed and often don't compensate for lower wages among lower-income Americans.

supporting.text: Certain professions in the U.S. have lower average salaries compared to their counterparts in countries with stronger labor protections and collective bargaining.

attacks.text: Certain professions in the U.S. have lower average salaries compared to their counterparts in countries with stronger labor protections and collective bargaining.
Many high-paying professions in the U.S., such as tech and finance, still outearn their counterparts in most other countries.
Even in high-paying sectors, U.S. workers often face higher costs of living and lack universal healthcare, reducing net disposable income.
Labor protections and collective bargaining can also lead to higher unemployment rates, offsetting wage gains in some countries.
Studies show that strong labor protections correlate with higher overall job satisfaction and productivity, mitigating unemployment concerns.

supporting.text: The U.S. lacks universal healthcare and other social benefits, which reduces disposable income compared to countries with comprehensive welfare systems.

attacks.text: The U.S. lacks universal healthcare and other social benefits, which reduces disposable income compared to countries with comprehensive welfare systems.
Many Americans have employer-sponsored healthcare and benefits, which can offset the lack of universal healthcare.
Employer-sponsored benefits are not universally accessible and often come with high out-of-pocket costs, reducing disposable income.
The U.S. has higher average salaries than many countries with comprehensive welfare systems, which can compensate for higher healthcare costs.
Higher salaries in the U.S. are often offset by higher costs of living, including healthcare, housing, and education.
